greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: The least integer k > 1 such that 1 + k^(5^n) + k^(2*5^n) + k^(3*5n) + k^(4*5^n) is prime.
comment: The primes correspond to k(1) through k(4) have a p-1 factorable up to 34% or higher, thus are proved prime by OpenPFGW.
The fifth one, Phi[5^6,18453]=1+18453^3125+18453^6250+18453^9375+18453^12500, is a 55326-digit Fermat and Lucas PRP with 78.86% proof.  A CHG proofing is running but it will take month to complete.
The sixth one, Phi[5^7,5517], has 233857 digits and can only be factored to about 26%.  It is too big for CHG to provide a proof.
link: Chris Caldwell, John Renze's Coppersmith-Howgrave-Graham PARI script
example: Phi[5^2,22] = 705429635566498619547944801 is prime, while Phi[25,k] with k = 2 to 21 are composites, so k(1)=22.
mathematica: Table[i = 1; m = 5^u; While[i++; cp = 1 + i^m + i^(2*m) + i^(3*m) + i^(4^m); ! PrimeQ[cp]]; i, {u, 1, 4}]
results.author: _Lei Zhou_, Feb 09 2012
